choices.text: Help in the phase I detoxification reaction
Transport of some amino acids across membranes in the kidney
Help in detoxification of electrophile compounds

questions.text: All of the following are important metabolic roles of glutathione except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glutathione is a conjugating agent, which is involved only in phase 2 of Detoxification, which comprises conjugation reactions.

The process of detoxification mainly involves 2 phases: Phase 1 and Phase 2.

Phase 1:

  • In phase 1 reactions, xenobiotics are converted to more polar, hydroxylated derivatives.
  • The main reaction involved is hydroxylation, which is catalysed by cytochrome P450 (a monooxygenase enzyme).

Phase 2:

  • In phase 2, hydroxylated derivatives from phase 1 are conjugated with molecules such as glutathione, glucuronic acid, or sulfate.
  • Conjugation renders them more water soluble, facilitating their eventual excretion in urine or bile.

Role of Glutathione in Phase 2 of Detoxification:

  • Glutathione is a tripeptide derived from Glycine, Cysteine, and Glutamic acid. Thus also known as gamma-glutamyl cysteinyl glycine.
  • It plays an important role in the phase 2 metabolism of electrophilic compounds.
    • Acts as a conjugating agent, helping in the detoxification of electrophilic compounds by forming glutathione S-conjugates that are excreted in urine and bile. (Option D)
    • This reaction is catalyzed by glutathione S-transferases.
  • Glutathione also provides the reducing agent for the reduction of hydrogen peroxide to water in the reaction catalysed by glutathione peroxidase.
  • Further, glutathione is an important intracellular reductant and antioxidant that helps to maintain essential SH groups of enzymes in their reduced state. (Option C)
  • A metabolic cycle involving glutathione as a carrier has been involved in the transport of certain amino acids across membranes in the kidney.
    • The first reaction of this cycle is catalysed by γ-glutamyltransferase (GGT):
      • Amino acid + GSH → γ-Glutamyl amino acid + Cysteinylglycine
    • This reaction helps in the transfer of amino acids across the plasma membrane as dipeptides. (Option B)

choices.text: Glycine is the simplest amino acid and shows optical inactivity
Glycine aminotransferases catalyse the synthesis of glycine from glyoxylate and glutamate or alanine.
The interconversion of Glycine to Serine is not possible.
Glycine can be synthesised from Choline and Serine.

questions.text: All are true regarding Glycine except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glycine:

  • The simplest amino acid. (Option A)
  • Non-essential amino acid.
  • Only achiral amino acid - hence optically inactive. (Option A)
  • Sarcosine (N-methyl glycine) is derived from glycine.
  • Glycine aminotransferases can catalyse the synthesis of glycine from glyoxylate and glutamate or alanine. (Option B)
  • Interconversion of Glycine to Serine is:
    • Catalysed by serine hydroxymethyltransferase
    • Freely reversible reaction.
    • Coenzymes required are Folic acid (Vitamin B9), Pyridoxal Phosphate (Vitamin B6)

Glycine can be synthesised from choline and serine. (Option D)

questions.text: Glycine is not involved in the synthesis of which of the following:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Catecholamines are synthesised from tyrosine and not glycine.

Functions of glycine:

  • Glutathione synthesis (Option C)
    • Glutathione is made up of three amino acids(tripeptide) - Glycine, Cysteine, and Glutamate. Also called gamma-glutamyl-glycine-cystine.
    • Glutathione is involved in free radical scavenging
    • Functions as an antioxidant and plays a role in detoxification.
  • Synthesis of purines - Adenine and guanine.
    • Contributes C4, C5 and N7 in the Purine ring.
  • Heme synthesis (Option B)
    • Glycine combines with succinylcholine to form δ-Aminolevulinic Acid, which is the rate-limiting step in heme biosynthesis.
  • Bile synthesis
    • Glycine conjugates with bile acids in the liver to form bile salts, which are more water-soluble and thus help in fat digestion and absorption.
  • Creatinine synthesis (Option A)
    • Glycine contributes to the synthesis of creatinine along with arginine and methionine, thus aiding energy metabolism.

questions.text: What is the primary metabolic defect in Primary Hyperoxaluria Type II?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary Hyperoxaluria Type II is associated with a deficiency of D-glycerate dehydrogenase (glyoxylate reductase enzyme complex)

Also known as Glyceric Aciduria.

Explanation of other options:

Glycine Cleavage System (Option A): A defect in the glycine cleavage system results in nonketotic hyperglycinemia. It's a rare inborn error of glycine degradation, resulting in the accumulation of glycine in body tissues, including the CNS.

Alanine Glyoxylate Aminotransferase (Option B):

  • Deficiency of Alanine Glyoxylate Aminotransferase results in Primary Hyperoxaluria Type I - the most common form of Primary Hyperoxaluria.
  • Alanine glyoxylate aminotransferase mediates the conversion of glyoxylate to glycine, a deficiency of which results in the accumulation of glyoxylate.
  • Accumulated glyoxylate gets oxidised to Oxalate (Oxalic acid) and gets excreted in urine, resulting in Oxalic aciduria and renal stones.
  • Alanine Glyoxylate Aminotransferase is a peroxisomal enzyme expressed only in the liver peroxisomes and requires pyridoxine (vitamin B6) as its cofactor.
  • Primary Hyperoxaluria Type I is a Protein-targeting defect.

Excess Vitamin C (Option D): Secondary hyperoxaluria results from non-genetic (acquired) causes, unlike Primary Hyperoxaluria, which is inherited. This can be due to:

  • Pyridoxine deficiency (cofactor for alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase)
  • Ethylene glycol poisoning.
  • High doses of vitamin C
  • In patients with inflammatory bowel disease or extensive resection of the bowel (enteric hyperoxaluria).

Key Takeaways:

  • Primary Hyperoxaluria Type 1: Deficiency of Alanine Glyoxylate Aminotransferase
  • Primary Hyperoxaluria Type 2: Deficiency of D-glycerate dehydrogenase

choices.text: It is a dipeptide involved in phase 2 of Detoxification
Aids in converting methemoglobin back to haemoglobin
It is composed of glycine, cysteine, and glutamate.
Acts as an oxidant by neutralising reactive oxygen species.

questions.text: All are true about glutathione except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glutathione is a tripeptide and not a dipeptide.

  • Glutathione is a tripeptide synthesised from the amino acids glycine, cysteine, and glutamate. (Option C)
  • Also known as gamma-glutamyl cysteinyl glycine.

Functions of Glutathione:

  1. Free radical scavenging: (Option D)
    • Glutathione (GSH) plays an important role in protecting cells from oxidative stress by neutralising reactive oxygen species.
    • Glutathione donates reducing equivalents (electrons) to detoxify free radicals, especially hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and lipid peroxides. This reaction is catalysed by glutathione peroxidase.
    • The oxidised form (GSSG) is then reduced back to GSH by glutathione reductase, using NADPH.
  2. Methemoglobin reduction: (Option B)
    • Aids in converting methemoglobin (Fe3+) back to haemoglobin (Fe2+), preventing cyanosis, and ensuring efficient oxygen transport.
  3. Conjugation and Detoxification of Xenobiotics:
    • Glutathione plays an important role in the phase 2 metabolism of Xenobiotics.
    • Acts as a conjugating agent, helping in the detoxification of electrophilic compounds by forming glutathione S-conjugates that are excreted in urine and bile.
    • This reaction is catalyzed by glutathione S-transferases.
  4. Further, glutathione is an important intracellular reductant and antioxidant that helps to maintain essential SH groups of enzymes in their reduced state.
  5. Glutathione helps in the transfer of amino acids across the plasma membrane as dipeptides.

choices.text: Help in the conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate
Disulfide bond formation between two adjacent peptide

questions.text: Sulfur of cysteine are not used/utilized in the body for the following process/product:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Methionine is an essential amino acid and therefore cannot be synthesised from Cysteine.
  • Instead, Cysteine, which is a non-essential amino acid, is synthesised from methionine via a transsulfuration reaction, in which the SH group from methionine is transferred to serine to form cysteine.

Explanation of other options:

Helps in conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate (Option A): Cysteine is transaminated to form beta mercapto pyruvate, which can transfer sulfur to cyanide to form thiocyanate, thus helping in detoxifying cyanide.

Thiosulfate formation (Option B): The catabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids, methionine, and cysteine can lead to thiosulfate formation.

Disulfide bond formation between two adjacent peptides (Option D): Two cysteine residues form a disulfide bond (-S-S-), stabilising the tertiary and quaternary structure of proteins like insulin and immunoglobulin. They play a crucial role in protein folding and stability.

choices.text: Impaired renal tubular reabsorption of dibasic amino acids
Occurs due to a defect in the amino acid transporters SLC6A19 and SLC7A9.
Defective metabolism of aromatic amino acids.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of renal colic. He has a family history of early-onset kidney stones. Urinalysis reveals hexagonal crystals and amino acid analysis shows increased excretion of lysine, arginine, and ornithine. Which of the following is true regarding the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above scenario is suggestive of Cystinuria. Impaired reabsorption of dibasic amino acids (lysine, arginine, ornithine, and cystine) in the proximal renal tubule leads to hexagonal cystine crystals and recurrent stones in cystinuria.

  • Cysteine is a non-essential and glucogenic amino acid
  • Contains a thiol group, capable of forming a disulfide bond.
  • It is found abundantly in the keratin of hair and nail. The more disulfide bonds, the harder the keratin is.
  • Synthesised from methionine via transsulfuration reaction involving the transfer of sulfur from the SH group of methionine to serine.

Cystinuria:

  • An inborn error of metabolism is characterised by a defect in amino acid transporters SLC3A1(Cystinuria Type 1) and SLC7A9 (Cystinuria Type 2).
  • Symptoms - Flank pain, vomiting, formation of hexagonal crystals in urine.
  • In Cystinuria, renal tubular and intestinal transport of dibasic amino acids Cysteine, ornithine, lysine, and arginine are affected.

Hexagonal crystals are seen in Cystinuria.

Explanation of other options:

Occurs due to a defect in the amino acid transporters SLC6A19 and SLC7A9 (Option B): A defect in the amino acid transporter SLC6A results in Hartnup disease. Hartnup disease is associated with defective intestinal and renal transport of tryptophan and other neutral amino acids.

Defective metabolism of aromatic amino acids (Option C): Defective metabolism of neutral amino acids also results in Hartnup disease.

Deficiency of cystathionine β-synthase (Option D): Cystathionine β-synthase deficiency results in homocystinuria, a metabolic disorder affecting methionine metabolism.

questions.text: Which amino acid in glutathione is responsible for its reducing property?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glutathione is a tripeptide (Glutamic acid + Cysteine + Glycine)
  • The -SH (sulfhydryl) group of cysteine is the active functional group that donates electrons to neutralise reactive oxygen species, making cysteine the key reducing component.
  • The active part of both Glutathione and N-acetyl cysteine is the Sulfhydryl group of Cysteine.
  • N-acetylcysteine is a precursor to cysteine that helps replenish glutathione levels.

Explanation of other options:

Glycine (Option B): Non-reactive component; serves a structural role in glutathione. Glycine is the C-terminal amino acid in glutathione but does not participate in redox reactions.

Glutamate (Option C): Involved in peptide linkage via an unusual γ-glutamyl bond, but not in reduction. It forms the backbone of the tripeptide, connecting to cysteine via its γ-carboxyl group, contributing to stability.

Alanine (Option D): Not a component of glutathione. Alanine is not present in the glutathione tripeptide and plays no role in its reducing property.

questions.text: What is Nitric Oxide synthesised from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesised in endothelial cells from arginine via the enzyme NO synthase, which is activated by calcium. The reaction converts arginine into NO and citrulline using NADPH and cofactors such as FAD, FMN, heme, and tetrahydrobiopterin.

  • NO diffuses into smooth muscle cells and activates soluble guanylyl cyclase.
  • This leads to increased cGMP production, activation of cGMP-dependent protein kinases, and vasodilation.
  • NO also inhibits platelet aggregation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Citrulline (Option B): Product; not a precursor. Citrulline is formed along with NO during the oxidation of arginine by NO synthase.

Alanine (Option C): Not involved. Alanine is a non-polar amino acid not related to NO synthesis.

Cysteine (Option D): Not the substrate. Though cysteine contains a thiol group important in redox reactions, it is not used in NO biosynthesis.

questions.text: A patient with suspected Folic acid deficiency was advised Histidine Load Test. Following the test, urine analysis showed elevated formiminoglutamic acid levels. Which among the following is the possible underlying defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metabolism of Histidine

  • The FIGLU Test, also known as the Histidine load test, is used to detect folate deficiency.
  • In the metabolism of the amino acid histidine, there is a folic acid-dependent step where formimino-glutamic acid (FIGLU) is converted to glutamic acid with the help of the enzyme Formimino transferase.
  • In folic acid-deficient patients, this reaction cannot be carried out; as a result, FIGLU accumulates in the blood and is excreted in urine.
  • FIGLU excretion in urine is an index of folic acid deficiency.
  • When a "loading dose" of histidine is given, the excretion of FIGLU in urine is increased further (Histidine loading test).

Explanation of other options:

Deficiency of histidase (Option A): Histidase catalyses non-oxidative deamination of histidine to Urocanic acid. Deficiency of histidase results in histidinemia.

Deficiency of histidine decarboxylase (Option B): Histidine decarboxylase is involved in the decarboxylation of histidine to histamine.

Deficiency of urocanase (Option C): Urocanase deficiency results in a defect in the conversion of urocanic acid to imidazolone propionic acid, resulting in urocanic aciduria.

Key Takeaways:

Histidine Load Test (also called 'FIGLU test')

  • To identify Folic Acid Deficiency.
  • FIGLU excreted in urine is measured following a Histidine load.

choices.text: NO is a potent muscle relaxant

questions.text: All are true about Nitric Oxide except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nitric Oxide acts through the second messenger cGMP and not cAMP.

Nitric Oxide

  • The uncharged molecule with an unpaired electron is a highly reactive, free radical.
    • Very short half-life (0.1 seconds)
    • Formerly called Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor
    • Gaseous molecules
    • The second messenger is cGMP
  • Arginine is a substrate for Nitric Oxide synthase, which converts it to Nitric Oxide and Citrulline.
  • Nitric Oxide Synthase is a cytosolic enzyme with three isoforms - iNOS, eNOS, and nNOS. The endothelial and neuronal forms of NO synthase are activated by Ca2+.

Functions of Nitric Oxide

  • Potent Vasodilator.
  • Involved in Penile erection
  • Neurotransmitters in the brain and the Peripheral Nervous System.
  • A low level of NO is involved in Pylorospasm in Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis.
  • Inhibit adhesion, activation and aggregation of Platelets.
  • Potent muscle relaxant

Explanation:

Biosynthesis of creatine and creatinine:

Creatine and creatinine are synthesised from three amino acids, namely:

  1. Glycine
  2. Arginine
  3. Methionine

Creatinine Synthesis:

  • In the first step, the amidino group of arginine is transferred to glycine to form guanidoacetic acid. This synthesis of guanidoacetic acid occurs in the kidney.
  • Guanidoacetic acid then undergoes a methylation reaction in the liver with the help of SAM to form creatine.
  • Creatine thus formed has two fates: either undergoes spontaneous conversion to creatinine or gets phosphorylated in the muscles to creatine phosphate.
  • Creatinine phosphate serves as an immediate source of energy in the muscle.

questions.text: Match the following amino acids with their respective decarboxylation products:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Decarboxylation Reactions:

Amino acids undergo an alpha decarboxylation reaction to form corresponding biological amines.

choices.text: The catabolism of proline occurs in mitochondria
Type II hyperprolinemia is associated with a deficiency of Proline dehydrogenase
Type II hyperprolinemia is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait.
Both Type I and II hyperprolinemia are associated with mental retardation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding proline metabolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Type I hyperprolinemia is associated with a deficiency of Proline dehydrogenase.

Proline:

  • The catabolism of proline takes place in mitochondria. (Option A)
  • There are two metabolic disorders of proline catabolism:
    1. Type I Hyperprolinemia: The Enzyme deficiency is proline dehydrogenase.
    2. Type II Hyperprolinemia: The Metabolic defect is the dehydrogenase that is involved in the conversion of glutamate-γ-semialdehyde to glutamic acid.
  • Both are inherited as autosomal recessive traits. (Option C)
  • Since proline does not participate in transamination, its α-amino nitrogen is retained throughout a two-stage oxidation to glutamate.
    • Oxidation to Δ1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate is catalysed by proline dehydrogenase.
    • Subsequent oxidation to glutamate is catalysed by Δ1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate dehydrogenase (also called glutamate-γ-semialdehyde dehydrogenase).
  • Inherited as autosomal recessive traits, both are associated with mental retardation. (Option D)

questions.text: A newborn presents with poor feeding, lethargy, and a characteristic maple syrup odour to the urine. On examination, there is hypotonia and intermittent apnea. Urine analysis in this infant will show which aminoacid/s?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-described clinical scenario in this infant is suggestive of Maple syrup urine disease. The basic biochemical defect is a deficiency of Branched Chain Ketoacid Dehydrogenase, resulting in the accumulation of branched-chain keto acids - Leucine, Isoleucine and Valine, which are then excreted in Urine.

Maple Syrup Urine Disease:

Biochemical defect

  • Deficiency of the enzyme Branched Chain Ketoacid Dehydrogenase.
  • Results in deficient decarboxylation of branched-chain keto acids - Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine.

Clinical features

  • Mental Retardation
  • Convulsion
  • Acidosis, Coma
  • Burnt Sugar [Maple Syrup] smell of urine (Due to excretion of branched-chain keto acid in urine)

Tests for MSUD

  • Di Nitro Phenyl Hydrazine Test (DNPH Test)
  • Rothera's Test (Positive)
  • Enzyme Analysis

Treatment

  • Restrict Branched Chain Amino Acid
  • Give high doses of Thiamine.

Explanation of Other Options:

Leucine, Lysine (Option A): Lysine is not a branched-chain amino acid.

Leucine only (Option C): Although leucine is elevated, isoleucine and valine are also involved.

Lysine only (Option D): Lysine is unrelated to MSUD.

Key Takeaways:

Maple Syrup Urine Disease is due to a deficiency in branched-chain ketoacid dehydrogenase, leading to the accumulation of leucine, isoleucine, and valine in blood and urine.

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a specific treatment for Isovaleric Acidemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glycine is used as a specific treatment for Isovaleric Acidemia to enhance the excretion of toxic metabolites.

  • Isovaleric acidemia:
  • Isovaleric acidemia is a metabolic disorder of branched-chain amino acid catabolism.
  • In isovaleric acidemia, ingestion of protein-rich foods elevates isovalerate, the deviation product of isovaleryl-CoA.
  • The impaired enzyme in isovaleric acidemia is isovaleryl-CoA dehydrogenase.
  • Vomiting, acidosis and coma follow ingestion of excess protein.
  • Accumulated isovaleryl-CoA is hydrolysed to isovalerate and excreted.
  • Treatment of Isovaleric Acidemia:
    • Hydration
    • Reversal of the catabolic state (by providing adequate calories orally or intravenously).
    • Correction of metabolic acidosis (by infusing sodium bicarbonate)
  • Removal of the excess isovaleric acid by:
    1. Administering Glycine: Because isovalerylglycine has a high urinary clearance, administration of glycine (250 mg/kg/24 hr) is recommended to enhance the formation of isovalerylglycine.
    2. Administering L-Carnitine: L-carnitine (100 mg/kg/24 hr orally) also increases the removal of isovaleric acid by forming isovalerylcarnitine, which is excreted in the urine

Explanation of other options:

Arginine (Option A): Basic amino acid; not involved in isovaleric acid detoxification. Used in other urea cycle disorders.

Lysine (Option B): Ketogenic amino acid; no role in isovaleric acidemia management.

Methionine (Option D): Sulfur-containing essential amino acid; not used in the treatment. May worsen metabolic load.

Key Takeaways:

Glycine is administered in isovaleric acidemia to facilitate detoxification by forming isovalerylglycine.
